normalised: Someone asked me the other day about the correct format for writing addresses, especially when dealing with government offices in India. It's trickier than you think! When I was younger, I remember messing up my application forms because I did not know the exact way to write the address. It's not just about the house number and street name; it's about the proper hierarchy and, honestly, sometimes deciphering what the actual address is. For example, trying to understand where "C-slash-o The Block Development Officer, Village plus Post Office: Mirzapur, District: Varanasi, U-P, two hundred and twenty one thousand three hundred and five" actually is can be a challenge.

unnormalised: See, you have to be meticulous. I always start with the individual's name or the department name, if sending something official. Then you include the building name or number, if available. After that comes the street name or locality. This is where you often see abbreviations like "St" for street or "Rd" for road. Next, the city or town, followed by the district (Dist:) if it's a rural area. Don't forget the state (e.g., MH for Maharashtra, TN for Tamil Nadu) and the all-important PIN code! Without the PIN, like 400001 for Mumbai GPO, your letter is as good as lost. Think of something addressed to "The Superintendent of Police, Civil Lines, Allahabad, UP". Could be anywhere in Civil Lines!
normalised: See, you have to be meticulous. I always start with the individual's name or the department name, if sending something official. Then you include the building name or number, if available. After that comes the street name or locality. This is where you often see abbreviations like "Street" for street or "Road" for road. Next, the city or town, followed by the district (District:) if it's a rural area. Do not forget the state (for example, M-H for Maharashtra, T-N for Tamil Nadu) and the all-important P-I-N code! Without the P-I-N, like four hundred thousand and one for Mumbai G-P-O, your letter is as good as lost. Think of something addressed to "The Superintendent of Police, Civil Lines, Allahabad, U-P". Could be anywhere in Civil Lines!

unnormalised: So, to summarize, a typical government address might look something like this: "The Director, National Informatics Centre, A-Block, CGO Complex, Lodhi Road, New Delhi, 110003". Following this order, with accurate details and the PIN code, will significantly increase the chances of your mail reaching its destination, even in the bureaucratic maze that is the Indian postal system! Remembering this has saved me a LOT of headaches.
